intro: Acacia aspera subsp. aspera, commonly known as the rough acacia, is a shrub or small tree native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its stiff, ridged, and often hairy leaves, which are typically arranged in pairs. The plant produces yellow to orange flowers in globular or cylindrical inflorescences, which are visited by various pollinators. Its wood is hard and durable, making it useful for construction and fuel. The species is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing resilience to drought and heat.

Its family is Fabaceae, commonly known as the legume or pea family, characterized by pod fruits and often nitrogen-fixing capabilities. Its genus is Acacia, a large genus of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive, often thorny appearance and nitrogen-fixing properties. Its species is Acacia aspera, a specific type within the Acacia genus known for its rough, hairy texture and adapted to arid environments.

It typically grows in open woodlands and along riverbanks. The plant is well adapted to the harsh climate conditions of the region. It plays an important role in the local ecosystem and is often used in traditional land management practices.
